wind.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: moving air, especially when it moves strongly or quickly in a current
wind.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The wind blew from the northeast.
Planes were unable to take off because of high winds.
knock the wind out of somebody (=hit someone in the stomach so that they cannot breathe for a moment)
wind.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the condition of having air or gas in your stomach or intestines, or the air or gas itself
wind.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I can’t drink beer – it gives me wind.
‘What’s wrong with the baby?’ ‘Just a little wind.’
wind.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: talk that does not mean anything
wind.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The wind was so strong he could hardly stand.
High winds are making driving conditions difficult.
There was a cold wind this afternoon.
She shivered in the icy wind.
A blustery wind was sending light flurries of rain against the window.
It will feel colder in places exposed to a fresh northeasterly wind.
He was buffeted by the gale force winds.
They sought shelter from the north wind.
A fresh northerly wind was speeding the ship southwards.
The prevailing wind comes from the west.
The rain beat down and the wind was picking up.
The wind had dropped a little.
The wind howled round the house all night.
The wind had to change before his fighting ships could sail against the Spanish.
A gust of wind rattled the window.
be blowing/swaying/flapping etc in the wind
The trees were all swaying in the wind.
Wind speeds of up to 80 miles an hour were recorded.
wind.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: air moving in a current, especially strongly or quickly
A cold wind was blowing from the east.
Strong winds caused damage to many buildings.
breeze
a gentle pleasant wind
The trees were moving gently in the breeze.
A slight breeze ruffled her hair.
draught
a current of cool air which blows into a room, especially one that makes you feel uncomfortable
There’s a bit of a draught in here – can you close the door?
a strong wind
gale
a very strong wind
The ship was blown off course in a severe gale.
Howling gales and torrential rain continued throughout the night.
hurricane
a storm that has very strong fast winds and that moves over water – used about storms in the North Atlantic Ocean
The hurricane devastated Florida and killed at least 40 people.
typhoon
a violent tropical storm – used about storms in the Western Pacific Ocean
A typhoon has hit the Philippines, lifting roofs off houses and uprooting trees.
tornado
a violent storm with strong winds that spin very quickly in a circle, often forming a cloud that is narrower at the bottom than the top
The town was hit by a tornado that damaged several homes.
cyclone
a violent tropical storm with strong winds that spin in a circle
A devastating cyclone struck Bangladesh in April that year.
This cyclone was traveling at speeds in excess of 21 miles per hour.
wind.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to turn or twist something several times around something else
wind.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The hair is divided into sections and wound around heated rods.
wind.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to turn part of a machine around several times, in order to make it move or start working
wind.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Did you remember to wind the clock?
wind.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if a road, river etc winds somewhere, it has many smooth bends and is usually very long
wind.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Highway 99 winds its way along the coast.
wind.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to make a tape move in a machine
wind.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Can you wind the video back a little way – I want to see that bit again.
wind.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to make someone have difficulty breathing, as a result of falling on something or being hit
wind.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The fall winded him and he lay still for a moment.
